# Complete Metric Space {#def-complete-metric-space}

A [Metric Space](../geometry/def-metric-space.qmd) $(X, d)$ is called **complete** if every [Cauchy Sequence](def-cauchy-sequence.qmd) in $X$ converges to a [Limit of a Sequence](def-limit.qmd) in $X$.

## Relationship to Convergence

- Every convergent sequence is a [Cauchy Sequence](def-cauchy-sequence.qmd)
- In a complete metric space, every [Cauchy Sequence](def-cauchy-sequence.qmd) converges
- A metric space is complete if and only if the converse holds: every [Cauchy Sequence](def-cauchy-sequence.qmd) converges

## Examples

**Complete metric spaces:**
- $\mathbb{R}$ with the standard metric (see [Real Line with Standard Metric](ex-real-line-metric.qmd))
- $\mathbb{C}$ with the standard metric
- Any closed subset of a complete metric space
- $C[a,b]$ (continuous functions on $[a,b]$) with the supremum metric (see [Normed Vector Space](def-normed-vector-space.qmd))

**Incomplete metric spaces:**
- $\mathbb{Q}$ with the standard metric (e.g., the sequence $(x_n)$ where $x_n$ is the $n$-th decimal approximation of $\sqrt{2}$ is a [Cauchy Sequence](def-cauchy-sequence.qmd) but doesn't converge in $\mathbb{Q}$)
- $(0, 1)$ with the standard metric
- $C[a,b]$ with the $L^1$ metric

## Importance

Completeness is crucial for:
- **Fixed point theorems**: The Banach fixed-point theorem requires completeness
- **Existence theorems**: Many existence results in analysis rely on completeness
- **Construction of $\mathbb{R}$**: The real numbers can be constructed as the completion of $\mathbb{Q}$ using [Cauchy sequences](def-cauchy-sequence.qmd)
